unnormalised: In the Indian healthcare system, precise measurements are crucial for accurate diagnoses and effective treatments. Healthcare professionals routinely use various units of measurement to assess patients' conditions, prescribe medications, and monitor treatment progress. Understanding these units is essential not just for medical personnel, but also for patients to better comprehend their health status and follow medical advice. This article aims to clarify some commonly used units of measurement in the Indian medical context.

unnormalised: One of the most frequently encountered measurements is body weight, typically expressed in kilograms (kg). For example, a patient might be described as weighing 75 kg, a key indicator for calculating medication dosages. Height is measured in centimeters (cm) or meters (m). A doctor might record a patient's height as 170 cm. Body Mass Index (BMI), calculated using weight and height (kg/m^2), is another important metric. normalised: One of the most frequently encountered measurements is body weight, typically expressed in kilograms. For example, a patient might be described as weighing seventy five kilograms, a key indicator for calculating medication dosages. Height is measured in centimeters or meters. A doctor might record a patient's height as one hundred and seventy centimeter. Body Mass Index (B-M-I), calculated using weight and height (kilograms divided by meter squared), is another important metric. A B-M-I of twenty eight kilograms per meter squared may indicate that a person is overweight. Also vital is recording body temperature, usually measured in degrees Celsius or degrees Fahrenheit. A normal body temperature is generally around thirty seven degree Celsius.

unnormalised: Blood pressure is another critical parameter, measured in millimeters of mercury (mmHg). A reading of 120/80 mmHg is considered normal, while a reading of 140/90 mmHg or higher may indicate hypertension. Blood glucose levels are often measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL). A fasting blood sugar level of 100 mg/dL can be a warning sign of pre-diabetes. For more accurate diabetes monitoring, HbA1c is measured in percentage (%). An HbA1c of 6.5 % or higher is usually indicative of diabetes. In respiratory care, oxygen saturation, often displayed as SpO2 %, helps determine the effectiveness of lung function.

For more accurate diabetes monitoring, H-b-A-one-c is measured in percentage. An H-b-A-one-c of six point five percent or higher is usually indicative of diabetes. unnormalised: Medication dosages are carefully prescribed in various units such as milligrams (mg), grams (g), and milliliters (mL). For instance, a doctor might prescribe 500 mg of paracetamol for fever or 10 mL of cough syrup. Intravenous (IV) fluids are often administered in liters (L) or milliliters (mL) over a specified time period. Monitoring fluid intake and output is also measured in ml or L, important especially for kidney failure patients. The concentration of electrolytes like sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) in the blood are expressed in milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L).
